The multiplicity of prime `p` in `p` is `1`

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → (Nat.factorization p) p = 1
name: Nat.Prime.factorization_self
docString: The multiplicity of prime `p` in `p` is `1`

If `p` is a prime number, then the divisors of `p` are exactly 1 and `p`.

type: ∀ {p m : ℕ}, p.Prime → (m ∣ p ↔ m = 1 ∨ m = p)
name: Nat.dvd_prime
docString: If `p` is a prime number, then the divisors of `p` are exactly 1 and `p`.

This theorem states that for every natural number `p`, if `p` is a prime number, then the set of proper divisors of `p` is the set that contains only the number `1`. In mathematical terms, it establishes that the proper divisors of a prime number `p` are only `1`, since prime numbers are defined as those natural numbers greater than 1 that have no other divisors besides `1` and themselves.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, p.Prime → p.properDivisors = {1}
name: Nat.Prime.properDivisors
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `p`, if `p` is a prime number, then the set of proper divisors of `p` is the set that contains only the number `1`. In mathematical terms, it establishes that the proper divisors of a prime number `p` are only `1`, since prime numbers are defined as those natural numbers greater than 1 that have no other divisors besides `1` and themselves.

The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself, with multiplicity `1`

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → Nat.factorization p = fun₀ | p => 1
name: Nat.Prime.factorization
docString: The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself, with multiplicity `1`

A natural number `p` is a prime factor of another natural number `n` if and only if `p` is a prime number, `p` divides `n`, and `n` is non-zero.

type: ∀ {n p : ℕ}, (p ∈ n.primeFactors) = (p.Prime ∧ p ∣ n ∧ n ≠ 0)
name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.PrimeFin._auxLemma.4
docString: A natural number `p` is a prime factor of another natural number `n` if and only if `p` is a prime number, `p` divides `n`, and `n` is non-zero.

This theorem states that for every natural number `p`, `p` is a prime number if and only if the integer equivalent of `p` is a prime element of a commutative monoid with zero. In other words, a natural number `p` is prime (i.e., it is at least 2 and its only divisors are `p` and `1`) if and only if when `p` is considered as an integer, it satisfies the properties of being a prime element in the context of a Commutative Monoid with Zero (i.e., `p` is not zero, is not a unit, and if `p` divides the product of two integers, then `p` must divide at least one of them).

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, p.Prime ↔ Prime ↑p
name: Nat.prime_iff_prime_int
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `p`, `p` is a prime number if and only if the integer equivalent of `p` is a prime element of a commutative monoid with zero. In other words, a natural number `p` is prime (i.e., it is at least 2 and its only divisors are `p` and `1`) if and only if when `p` is considered as an integer, it satisfies the properties of being a prime element in the context of a Commutative Monoid with Zero (i.e., `p` is not zero, is not a unit, and if `p` divides the product of two integers, then `p` must divide at least one of them).

The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself.

type: ∀ {p q : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → (Nat.factorization p) q ≠ 0 → p = q
name: Nat.Prime.eq_of_factorization_pos
docString: The only prime factor of prime `p` is `p` itself.

The only prime divisor of positive prime power `p^k` is `p` itself

type: ∀ {k p : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → Nat.Prime p → (p ^ k).primeFactors = {p}
name: Nat.primeFactors_prime_pow
docString: The only prime divisor of positive prime power `p^k` is `p` itself

A prime `p` satisfies `p % 2 = 1` if and only if `p ≠ 2`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p % 2 = 1 ↔ p ≠ 2
name: Nat.Prime.mod_two_eq_one_iff_ne_two
docString: A prime `p` satisfies `p % 2 = 1` if and only if `p ≠ 2`.

The `p`-adic norm of an integer is at most `1`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] (z : ℤ), padicNorm p ↑z ≤ 1
name: padicNorm.of_int
docString: The `p`-adic norm of an integer is at most `1`.

The `p`-adic norm respects division.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] (q r : ℚ), padicNorm p (q / r) = padicNorm p q / padicNorm p r
name: padicNorm.div
docString: The `p`-adic norm respects division.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

name: Nat.dvd_left_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [dec_irr : (p : Associates α) → Decidable (Irreducible p)]
  [inst_1 : UniqueFactorizationMonoid α] [dec : DecidableEq α] [dec' : DecidableEq (Associates α)] {a p : Associates α},
  Irreducible p →
    ∀ [inst_2 : (n : ℕ) → Decidable (a ∣ p ^ n)] {n : ℕ} (h : a ∣ p ^ n),
      a = p ^ Nat.find (_ : ∃ n, (fun n => a ∣ p ^ n) n)
name: Associates.eq_pow_find_of_dvd_irreducible_pow
docString: The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers.

Two pnats are coprime if their gcd is 1.

type: ℕ+ → ℕ+ → Prop
name: PNat.Coprime
docString: Two pnats are coprime if their gcd is 1.

If the factorization of `n` contains just one number `p` then `n` is a power of `p`

type: ∀ {n p k : ℕ}, n ≠ 0 → (Nat.factorization n = fun₀ | p => k) → n = p ^ k
name: Nat.eq_pow_of_factorization_eq_single
docString: If the factorization of `n` contains just one number `p` then `n` is a power of `p`

`ζ - 1` is prime if `ζ` is a primitive `p`-th root of unity.

type:
∀ {p : ℕ+} {K : Type u} [inst : Field K] [inst_1 : CharZero K] {ζ : K} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime ↑p)]
  [h : IsCyclotomicExtension {p} ℚ K] (hζ : IsPrimitiveRoot ζ ↑p), Prime (IsPrimitiveRoot.toInteger hζ - 1)
name: IsPrimitiveRoot.zeta_sub_one_prime'
docString: `ζ - 1` is prime if `ζ` is a primitive `p`-th root of unity.

The `p`-adic norm of an integer `m` is one iff `p` doesn't divide `m`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] (m : ℤ), padicNorm p ↑m = 1 ↔ ¬↑p ∣ m
name: padicNorm.int_eq_one_iff
docString: The `p`-adic norm of an integer `m` is one iff `p` doesn't divide `m`.

The `p`-adic norm of `q` is `1` if `q` is prime and not equal to `p`.

type: ∀ {p q : ℕ} [p_prime : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] [q_prime : Fact (Nat.Prime q)], p ≠ q → padicNorm p ↑q = 1
name: padicNorm.padicNorm_of_prime_of_ne
docString: The `p`-adic norm of `q` is `1` if `q` is prime and not equal to `p`.

The `p`-adic value of a natural is its `p`-adic value as an integer.

type: ∀ {p n : ℕ}, padicValInt p ↑n = padicValNat p n
name: padicValInt.of_nat
docString: The `p`-adic value of a natural is its `p`-adic value as an integer.

A number satisfying the Liouville condition with exponent `p > 1` is an irrational number.

type: ∀ {p x : ℝ}, LiouvilleWith p x → 1 < p → Irrational x
name: LiouvilleWith.irrational
docString: A number satisfying the Liouville condition with exponent `p > 1` is an irrational number.

if `p` factors then one factor is a unit

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : Monoid α] {p : α}, Irreducible p → ∀ (a b : α), p = a * b → IsUnit a ∨ IsUnit b
name: Irreducible.isUnit_or_isUnit'
docString: if `p` factors then one factor is a unit

`2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `7` mod `8`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p ≠ 2 → (IsSquare 2 ↔ p % 8 = 1 ∨ p % 8 = 7)
name: ZMod.exists_sq_eq_two_iff
docString: `2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `7` mod `8`.

The `p`-adic norm of `1` is `1`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ}, padicNorm p 1 = 1
name: padicNorm.one
docString: The `p`-adic norm of `1` is `1`.

`Nat.Prime p` means that `p` is a prime number, that is, a natural number
at least 2 whose only divisors are `p` and `1`.

type: ℕ → Prop
name: Nat.Prime
docString:
`Nat.Prime p` means that `p` is a prime number, that is, a natural number
at least 2 whose only divisors are `p` and `1`.
